messages.content: Hi, is there any good documentation, discussion here on DC, or other resource for learning about the boundaries of actions?  I'm assuming that there's some limit to the number of actions that can be stored on chain (if any?).  I know that there is a limit to the number of actions that can be reduced in one call to the reducer, but I don't know the exact criteria there.  Is it number of account updates, or size in fields of the input, or number of gate computations?  All of the above?

your first bottleneck is circuit size, if your circuit processes 10 actions then per action you can consume max 2^16/10 constraints, therefore you must do it recursively otherwise you will run into systemic issues.

one systemic issue can be that if there’s more than 10 actions waiting to be processed, you may not be able to process enough actions to catch up with historical sequence state (5 historical seq state precondition)

Then you’re still limited to 8-9 AUs per each reduce tx.

Ok so assuming I can call reduce on every block, there can only be 10 actions added per block?  Otherwise, some actions will just get dropped?  Or will it become impossible to process any additional actions?  Like the hash becomes obsolete or something?

I don't think the reducer uses recursion currently, so theoretically you can run into a situation where you literally can not do anything because the action_state field has gone too far into the future
because you need to prove what's in it
@gregor can disconfirm hopefully
No Las is right
But that's a limitation of how 'reduce()' is written, not one of actions
In a production app I'd recommend to either write a recursive reduce or add a recursive 'hashchain' proof which connects processed actions to the current state
@45930, there is no hard limit of '10 actions per reduce'. The limit is the circuit size - and there's the fact that you have to pick _some_ limit to get a static circuit
The current default is 32 actions per reduce, and reduce assumes that those 32 are enough to connect with onchain state.

Btw, with chunking, there will be no circuit size limit anymore (chunking is done on the crypto side, will be brought to o1js as one of our next projects)
But there's still the fact that you need to pick a limit bc circuits are static

It seems like there’s a limit of how many actions are stored on chain and how many gates are used by some list of actions.  Is every action in the past n blocks stored on chain? Or just the past n actions regardless of block height?
What happens if more than 32 actions are emitted?  We lose the ability to ever process actions again?  E.g. the contract is bricked?  Or can we just drop some and continue to process new ones?
contract is bricked
No actions at all are stored on chain, just a hash of all of them
So that's not the problem

Using actions (i.e. `reduce()` and similar patterns) works as follows: You fetch actions from the archive node. Then you prove that you can hash them to the same hash that's stored onchain. Thus, you proved that you have the correct actions in your circuit. Then, do whatever you want with them.
It's like a Merkle tree except that it's not a tree, but a linear list

Ok, I think I'm with you!  The action overflow bricking a contract seems to disqualify this pattern from any serious usage.  At least in an app where number of users can scale up.  It could work with some kind of rollup where only one or a handful of authorized users can emit acitons and those users are careful not to overflow.  Does that seem correct?
aaand this is why we wrote Protokit! to process actions recursively 🤟

@maht0rz what's the design of data storage for protokit?  It's convenient to rely on archive nodes making action data available.  Will app chains be able to use something similar, or will each app chain be responsible for its own data availability?
you can use actions as a mempool for a protokit appchain, then its the same as if you used reducer - but without issues
the underlying app chain protocol has been designed with sequence state in mind, so the recursive circuitry can attest that it processed a hash of actions
What you really want for actions is folding
to prove merkle list extension
thankfully they're on it AFAIU

I get this error trying to use actions on Berkeley: `Error: fetchActions: Specified GraphQL endpoint is undefined. Please specify a valid endpoint.`

Where do I set an endpoint?  Is there an example for working with a live blockchain?
This has nothing to do with actions, you need to do what it says in the error quite literally.
You need to set a URL to a GraphQL endpoint.
Can't remember the exact invocation but it's in most examples.

I'm able to fetch my account state and send transactions via the normal graphQL endpoint.  This fails specifically when calling `reduceVotes()` on my zkapp (which is my method which reduces the action state).
wtf
I assume it needs a different endpoint for the archive node, not just the mina network state.  I just don't know where to set that (or what a good value for it is).
oh right
@45930 https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/fetch.ts#L61

embeds.title: o1js/src/lib/fetch.ts at main · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: networkConfig.archiveEndpoint
@45930 setArchiveGraphqlEndpoint
is probably it

Could it be that fetching actions from a remote node isn't supported yet, @45930 ? Back in January I had this issue, but not sure if it was already solved, since my current project doesn't use actions:
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1068010900713373767/1068030273075281960

events/actions are being stored only on archive nodes
https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/fetch-events-and-actions#fetching-actions-from-an-archive-node

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content:
Thanks Las, this was it - but as @chrlyz says, I don't think it works.  I just got to the next error which is `Error: Must provide query string.`.

@gregor could you confirm that this doesn't yet work on Berkeley?  Or is it possible that I still just have something misconfigured?
No it works. If you have an archive node that works. The endpoint is set by passing it to Mina.Network()

Do you know of an endpoint that works?  I am trying `https://api.minascan.io/archive/berkeley/v1/graphql` but I get the error above: `Must provide query string` from this line: `let response = await fetchActions({ publicKey, actionStates, tokenId }, archiveEndpoint);`
"must provide query string" - where is this coming from? From the graphql response?
It's throwing on `if (error) throw Error(error.statusText);`, but if I run that graphQL query against the graphiql interface on minascan, it works
Ok, sorry for the confusion.  I plugged in `https://archive.berkeley.minaexplorer.com` instead and it worked.  @Ducca | Staketab do you want to DM me and see if we can troubleshoot the minascan path?
Sure, will dm you soon

Hey actions gang - I am trying to polish off my mina navigators demo, but the second time I reduced my actions, I got an "account state precondition unsatisfied" [error](https://berkeley.minaexplorer.com/transaction/5JuAix3exhSHzuLMSVSusY4iVVJpMPMvmUr3Wyp9Us8DtKvPA6Sz).  I added a unit test, and reducing twice seems to work, any ideas why it wouldn't on berkeley?
To confirm, the first time I reduced an action, it worked, and updated the state of my app:
check which precondition is unsatisfied, you can find them in the transaction

Great idea, thanks!

To me, it looks like `actionState: 8506850415162260991926896150945735760729556917750956697997340105227221897389`  is the winner, since that is not my most recent action state hash.

Could that mean that the archive node has some different action history than what is committed to on chain?  Or am I mis-reading?  The only other precondition I see is state 6 being the current on chain value of state 6.
any of the 5 "most recent" action states is valid (with some extra logic)
this might be your issue
your the valid action states, an account has 5 recorded
when you add an action it will replace the newest one, and _some times_ push the old one up
IIRC, if updated before in same block, don't, otherwise, push up
Yeah it seems like it's action state, and that one isn't anywhere in the history. You can `Provable.log()` those fetched actions, to see what is being reduced.
Hmm so somehow my mina node and archive node are out of sync?  Yeesh
Thanks @Las and @Faserisko !
Yes it only pushes new if it's new block

It looks like that you are reducing more actions that are on mina node. https://archive.berkeley.minaexplorer.com/ this archive node doesn't have it as well. Maybe you've got it cached locally because some transaction didn't go through?
The mina graphQL node and the archive node disagree about this state, right?  It seems like the archive node didn't pick up the latest action.
I don't think it would be something cached locally, but I will try installing it fresh
